results.title: More or less: a film about food
results.creator_credit: Lawrie Whittle, Paddy Stitt and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: Andrew Daddo outlines the “More or less” diet which is advocated by the Life Be In It campaign as a plan for eating for the “rest of your life”. By choosing carefully from the five basic food groups and eating more bread, cereals, fruit and vegetables, and less sugar, fat and salt, and exercising regularly, more children can became aware of the choices involved in planning a balanced diet.

results.title: No more Hiroshima
results.creator_credit: Martin Duckworth, Jacques Vallee and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A documentary film portrait of two survivors of the atomic bomb droped on Hiroshima. They are among the minority of survivors who have decided to risk their careers and marriage prospects by identifying themselves with “Hobusyka”. The film follows them as they travel to New York to represent the Japanese peace movement at the second United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in June 1982. Excellent for senior students.

results.title: Visually speaking. Parts 1-6
results.creator_credit: Don White, Yaletown Productions Inc. and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: 1. “Body talking”. Begins the sequence by exploring the power of visual images as a source of information and means of communication. 2.”A sense of touch” 3. “A sense of sound”. These two segments extend the power of visual imagery by showing how it connects with information from other senses to enrich the meaning we gain from our experiences. 4. “Speaking object-ly”. Provides a transition from the literal interpretation of visual imagery to the more abstract concept that what we see carries implicit subjective messages. 5. “Sequence and story”. Shows how visual images are connected to one another and how our interpretations can be changed as we explore how our images of them are related to one another. 6. “Movie movie”. Deals directly with ways in which visual images can be manipulated to influence our thoughts and emotions.

results.title: Waves in the ocean: Yrs 8-12
results.brief_description: Shows the beauty and order behind the movement of ocean waves. Includes: generation of waves in water, speed and length, how waves bend and change direction, beach building, reflection and wave motion.

results.title: Glass menagerie
results.creator_credit: Paul Newman, Burtt Harris and Columbia
results.brief_description: A shy girl seeks escape from reality of life in the St. Louis of the Great Depression and from her mother’s fantasies of constantly reliving the glory of her youth. The fragile balance of the family is changed when her brother arranges for a “gentleman caller” to pay a visit. Based on the play by Tennesse Williams. Stars Joanne Woodward, John Malkovich and Karen Allen.

results.title: Return to Dresden
results.creator_credit: Martin Duckworth, Jacques Vallee and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A record of a visit to Dresden, East Germany, by allied airmen who fire bombed the city during World War II and who are now members of the peace movement. Both the airmen and survivors of the bombing share their opinions against a backdop of archival footage of the raid. Challenges the viewer to wonder why human beings continue to inflict pain and suffering on one another.

results.title: Science and money
results.creator_credit: Mike Milne, Michael Coyle and BBC
results.brief_description: While this program is about British coinage, the information on coin alloys and the reasoning for notes versus coins remains relevant. Shows coins actually being tested from the basic alloy through the entire production process.

results.title: What should happen?: investigating community decision making
results.creator_credit: James Mann and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: An account of how a Year 9/10 class investigate a local issue, and in doing so, learn about the political process. Demonstrates the inquiry process in practice, emphasising collaborative learning, well planned field work and classroom reflection. Students are able to observe the tactics used by protagonists to influence the decision-making process.
